sciknow-25x1-scientific-papers.title: API Governance at Scale
sciknow-25x1-scientific-papers.abstract:
API Governance, the process of applying standardized sets of policies and guardrails to the design and development of APIs, has only grown in importance and prominence given the continued growth in APIs being produced. In this paper, we present an Action Research style approach to investigate and understand the utility of a multi-faceted API Governance process being adopted inside Google. We first reflect on past research around API Governance, and then introduce three new components, 1. API Improvement Proposals (AIPs) the documented source of truth for API design rules, 2. API Linter, an automated analysis tool which checks for adherence to / violations of AIPs, and 3. API Readability, a program to educate and certify API design experts. These three components are designed to build upon pre-existing processes to scale and improve API design. Through a mixed-methods research strategy, containing both a survey and a series of interviews, we evaluate the utility of these approaches in supporting API Producers. Our research shows that API Producers have positive sentiment towards API Governance, validating the general direction of the program. Specifically, our study participants highlighted the positive impact of API Governance on the quality of the APIs they produced, via consistency in both the outcome and approach. This paper also discusses future research opportunities to enhance API Governance, specifically with regards to newer API Producers, who reported worse sentiment towards the program than their more experienced peers.

## CCS Concepts

· Software and its engineering → Software development methods ; Software design engineering .

## Keywords

API governance, API design

## ACMReference Format:

Mak Ahmad, JJ Geewax, Andrew Macvean, David Karger, and Kwan-Liu Ma. 2024. API Governance at Scale. In 46th International Conference on

sciknow-25x1-scientific-papers.journal: and then introduce three new components

guidingModels.relevance: Used to investigate and understand the utility of a multi-faceted API Governance process at Google

sciknow-25x1-research-problems.problemStatement: The research addresses the challenge of scaling API governance to support API producers in designing high-quality APIs, particularly in the context of a rapidly growing number of APIs that outpaces the capacity of API design reviewers.
sciknow-25x1-research-problems.problemScope: The scope includes the development and implementation of standardized API governance processes within a large organization, specifically Google, and the evaluation of these processes' utility in improving API design quality and consistency.
sciknow-25x1-research-problems.problemImportance: The problem is significant because usable APIs are crucial for developer productivity, code re-use, and preventing software bugs and security issues. Effective API governance ensures consistency and quality in API design, which is increasingly important as the number of APIs grows.
sciknow-25x1-research-problems.businessRelevance: Solving this problem is relevant to businesses that rely on APIs for their products and services, as it can lead to improved developer experience, faster time-to-market, and reduced costs associated with API inconsistencies and usability issues.

sciknow-25x1-knowledge-gaps.gapDescription: The process of onboarding new users to API Governance needs to be more valuable and easier, as newer users do not see the same value as more experienced colleagues.
sciknow-25x1-knowledge-gaps.gapSignificance: Improving the onboarding process for new users is crucial for the adoption and effective use of API Governance tools and practices.

sciknow-25x1-knowledge-gaps.gapDescription: There is a need to quantify if API Improvement Proposals (AIPs) and/or the API Linter are producing better APIs from both a production and consumption perspective.
sciknow-25x1-knowledge-gaps.gapSignificance: Understanding the impact of AIPs and the API Linter on API quality is essential for validating their effectiveness and guiding future improvements.

sciknow-25x1-knowledge-gaps.gapDescription: Further research is needed to analyze the effectiveness of individual AIPs, such as AIP-155 and AIP-164, to determine their specific contributions to API quality.
sciknow-25x1-knowledge-gaps.gapSignificance: Evaluating individual AIPs can help refine API design principles and ensure that they address the most critical aspects of API quality.

sciknow-25x1-knowledge-gaps.gapDescription: There is a need for automated systems to transmit expertise from reviewers to producers for complex use cases, potentially involving updates to the AIPs themselves.
sciknow-25x1-knowledge-gaps.gapSignificance: Automating the transfer of expertise can reduce the burden on human reviewers and scale the API design review process more effectively.

sciknow-25x1-knowledge-gaps.gapDescription: Research into leveraging large language models for automatically generating API specifications based on a list of requirements is necessary to move towards full automation.
sciknow-25x1-knowledge-gaps.gapSignificance: Automating API specification generation can significantly reduce manual labor and streamline the API design process.

sciknow-25x1-research-questions.questionText: How can we continue scaling the API design review program to not only review more APIs, but also reduce turnaround time, all while striving to maintain the quality of the review process?
How do we build a program to effectively support API Producers in designing high quality APIs?
Do AIPs and/or the API Linter really make APIs better?
Can we find a way to define API goodness?
How do we make the process more valuable and easier for new users?

relatedVariables.variableName: Ease of use for new users

sciknow-25x1-future-directions.directionDescription: Evaluate the usability of the tools provided to reduce friction in the process of adopting and utilizing them, such as improving the search functionality of AIP.Dev and the installation experience of the linter.

Explore ways to evangelize the importance of API Governance and API Design best practices, while also exploring ways to address some of the common API Design problems identified as challenging in past research.
Investigate how to make the API Governance process more valuable and easier for new users, potentially utilizing it as a formal teaching and learning mechanism.
Continue investigation around ensuring a single source of truth for API Design guidelines and addressing issues around diverging or inconsistent guidance.

Encourage and empower developers to be more involved in submitting PRs to change AIPs, and capture in the moment why overrides of linter guidance are happening to create a positive feedback loop which updates the best practices.
Find automated systems of transmitting expertise from reviewers to producers to solve complex use cases which may involve updating the AIPs themselves.

Leverage large language models to automatically code the API specifications based on a list of requirements, refining AIPs to make the future transition to AI generated API design specifications more feasible.

Analyze why APIs are being reviewed and then pick out pieces that can be automated, with the goal of making API design reviews an exception and scaling the API design review process with a small set of reviewers.
Quantify if AIPs and/or the API Linter are in fact producing better APIs both from a production and consumption perspective, and define API goodness.
Conduct further research in analyzing the effectiveness of individual AIPs, such as AIP-155 resource identification or AIP-164 soft delete.

sciknow-25x1-scientific-challenges.challengeDescription: Scaling the API design review process to handle the growing number of APIs being produced without compromising the quality and consistency of the reviews.
Ensuring consistency in feedback and balancing API expertise with product domain expertise during API design reviews.
Developing a citable and unambiguous style guide for API design that enables engineers to develop consistent, scalable, and flexible API specifications.
Automating the assignment of API design reviewers to API launch requests in a scalable and efficient manner.
Creating a process that supports API producers in building usable APIs efficiently, while introducing friction in the right ways.

sciknow-25x1-limitations.limitationDescription: The API Governance process, AIPs and Linter was specifically designed for a single organization, which may not be generalizable to other organizations with different sizes and tooling resources.
sciknow-25x1-limitations.impactOnFindings: The findings may not be applicable to other organizations with different structures or resources, potentially limiting the broader applicability of the research results.
sciknow-25x1-limitations.businessConstraints: Other organizations may not be able to replicate the governance process without adjustments to fit their specific context, which could involve additional costs, scalability challenges, or different implementation strategies.

sciknow-25x1-limitations.limitationDescription: Selection bias may be present as the survey participants were from Google's API interest group and may have been more inclined to respond positively given the process came from their employer.
sciknow-25x1-limitations.impactOnFindings: The positive sentiment reported towards the API Governance process may be inflated due to the participants' affiliation with the organization that developed the process.
sciknow-25x1-limitations.businessConstraints: The positive outcomes reported may not be as pronounced in organizations where the governance process is not internally developed, potentially affecting buy-in and adoption rates.

sciknow-25x1-limitations.limitationDescription: The low participation rate from the interest group members (3%) could indicate that the sample may not be representative of the entire population of API producers.
sciknow-25x1-limitations.impactOnFindings: The results may not accurately reflect the sentiments of the larger population of API producers, which could affect the reliability of the conclusions drawn.
sciknow-25x1-limitations.businessConstraints: If the sample is not representative, businesses may not see the same level of benefits when implementing the governance process, leading to discrepancies between expected and actual outcomes.

sciknow-25x1-limitations.limitationDescription: Participants who already had API Readability could be biased in classifying API design reviews as effective, which may skew the results.
sciknow-25x1-limitations.impactOnFindings: The study's conclusions regarding the effectiveness of API design reviews may be overly optimistic due to the potential bias of participants with API Readability.
sciknow-25x1-limitations.businessConstraints: Businesses may overestimate the effectiveness of API design reviews based on these results, which could lead to misallocation of resources or disappointment with the process.

sciknow-25x1-methodological-frameworks.name: API Governance at Scale - Methodological Framework
sciknow-25x1-methodological-frameworks.description: The study employs an Action Research style approach to investigate and understand the utility of a multi-faceted API Governance process at Google. The research is conducted in two phases: a large-scale survey and a series of in-depth interviews. The survey aims to capture broad sentiment towards API Governance, while the interviews seek to delve deeper into participants' experiences. The study focuses on three new components of API Governance: API Improvement Proposals (AIPs), an API Linter, and the API Readability program. The methodology includes a mixed-methods research strategy, combining quantitative data from the survey with qualitative insights from the interviews.

studyDesign.designDetails: The study uses a mixed-methods approach, integrating quantitative survey data with qualitative interview data to evaluate the effectiveness of the API Governance process. The research is cross-sectional, capturing sentiments and experiences at a single point in time.

populationAndSampling.targetPopulation: The target population includes members of the Google API interest group, which consists of individuals interested in various aspects of APIs. The population is likely to contain a significant proportion of those actively designing APIs at Google.
populationAndSampling.inclusionCriteria: Participants who have completed an API Design Review in the last 2 years and have interacted with the API Governance features.

steps.description: Develop and distribute the survey to the Google API interest group.

procedures.procedureDescription: A large-scale survey containing likert-style and open-ended questions was administered to members of the Google API interest group to measure perceptions towards API Design and API Governance.

steps.description: Select a random subset of survey participants who opted in for further research phases.
Conduct semi-structured interviews exploring participants' backgrounds and their detailed responses from the survey.

procedures.procedureDescription: Semi-structured interviews were conducted with a subset of survey participants to explore their experiences with API Governance in greater detail.

dataCollection.instrumentDescription: The survey instrument included likert-style questions to quantify sentiments and open-ended questions to collect qualitative feedback.
dataCollection.collectionSetting: The survey was distributed electronically to members of the Google API interest group.
dataCollection.collectionTimeframe: Data collection occurred over a period consistent with the survey distribution and response period.

dataAnalysis.parameterSettings: False Discovery Rate set at 0.1 with a significance level of 0.0456
dataAnalysis.dataPreprocessingSteps: Coding of qualitative responses and transcription of interviews
dataAnalysis.summary: Descriptive statistics were computed for likert-style survey responses. Kendall rank test and Benjamini-Hochberg procedure were used for correlation analysis. Qualitative responses from both the survey and interviews were coded using lightweight content analysis by the primary authors. Transcribed interviews were also coded using the same process.

resultsRepresentation.summary: The study found overall positive sentiment towards the API Governance process, with specific components such as AIPs, the API Linter, and API Readability program being well-received. Correlations between experience with API reviews and perceptions of the linter's helpfulness were identified. Some areas for improvement were also noted, such as the need for better community engagement in AIPs and the occasional need to override linter guidance.

sciknow-25x1-material-tools.roleInProcedure: Used for driving nails into wood
